text: (playful music)
- Hello,
and happy New Year to all our viewers.
And for our regulars,

welcome back to the
VMware on AWS Update Show

with a little delay to our
very first episode of 2024,
the March edition.
For those who are new to the show,
in this series, we bring you up to speed
with new releases and features
and general news
on everything related to VMware and AWS.

Plus, we'll let you know about
any recently released blogs,
articles, reference architectures,
and customer case studies.
Each show, we select one or two items
from the list of updates,

and with our guests, we dive
a little deeper into them.

Now, as you may have noticed,
I'm now Chris Porter,

and it is with a heavy
heart that I announce

that he has actually
moved on to another role
in greener pastures.
But it is with great pleasure
that I would like to introduce you
to our new co-host, Senay Swinney,
who is a Specialist Solutions Architect
for VMC on AWS.
- Thanks, Dries.
It's my pleasure to be joining the team.
On the agenda for today's show,
we've got regular round of updates
from the world of VMware Cloud and AWS.
This month,

we'll dive deeper into
advanced security features

included out of the box
in VMware Cloud on AWS,

and we'll cover a recent
feature enhancements available
with VMware Cloud Disaster Recovery,

as well as new blogs and
customers case studies.
- Exciting.
Let's get into it.
(playful music)
- For this month,

we have updates covering a
number of different services.

Let's start with VMware
Cloud Disaster Recovery,
VCDR for short.
There've been significant changes to VCDR.
With the recent announcements

that we now support 15 minute
Recovery Point Objective
down from 30 minutes.
There have been a number of enhancement
to the ransom recovery capability.

We'll cover in more
detail later in the show
with our special guest.

Secondly, M7i.metal is
now generally available
for VMware cloud and AWS in five regions.
It's been a few months

since it was announced
at AWS re:Invent 2023.
The M7i.metal

is going to change the way
we approach storage heavy VMC
on AWS deployments.
AWS announced on the 29th of February,

the general availability
of Amazon EC2 M7i instance
for VMware Cloud on AWS.
With this launch,

customers can get the
experience improved flexibility

and greater control over
their infrastructure
as they get to choose their storage
and compute options independently.
This offering features

a desegregated storage
architecture from compute

supporting both Amazon
FSx for NetApp ONTAP

and VMware Cloud Flex Storage
as primary storage options
for customers.
With this new offering,
customers can now choose among

three different instance
types for VMware Cloud on AWS.
I3en,
I4i
and M7i finally.
This list instance allow customers
to choose their storage
and compute options
independently

providing flexibility, control
and optimized infrastructure.

VMware Cloud and AWS
customers can leverage
the M7i.metal instance
in the following AWS regions.
North Virginia, Ohio, Oregon,
Ireland, and Stockholm.

More regions expected to be
added to the list very soon.
- Next up, advanced security features

are now included out of the
box in VMware Cloud on AWS.
Firstly, we have Layer 7 Application ID.
With this capability,

customers can create
microsegmentation security policies

at more granular level
for specific applications
after determining
which workloads comprise which application

and what network traffic is
necessary for the application.
It can also restrict any other traffic,
hence reducing the attack surface.
The second feature is FQDN filtering.
With this capability,

security administrators
can define firewall rules

that explicitly provide
access to a set of FQDNs
and can control or restrict access
to remote services and sites.

The last feature is User
Identity-based Firewall or IDFW.
With this capability,
customers can create firewall rules
based on active directory
or LDAP user groups

in order to provide granular
access control to applications.
- Moving on to blogs and videos

and customer case studies
published in February.
The first blog incorporates
using Identity and Access Management,
IAM for short,

Roles Anywhere to help secure
VMware Cloud on AWS workloads.

It's been written by Mithil
Rangdale and Rahul Gupta.
In this post,
we cover how AWS IAM Roles Anywhere
can enhance the security of workloads
running on VMware Cloud on AWS
and their integration with AWS services.
It goes into common use cases

where workloads running
on VMware Cloud on AWS
need access to AWS native services

along with the advantages
of using IAM Roles Anywhere
for credential management,

as well as demonstration of how
to set up IAM Roles Anywhere

for workloads running
on VMware Cloud on AWS.
- Second is a customer case study.
It's on how Quality Bicycle Products,
or QBP for short,

migrated to VMware Cloud
on AWS in under 18 months.
QBP had a tight timeframe

of 14 to 18 months to
complete the migration
making VMware Cloud on AWS a perfect path
that allowed QBP

to quickly move existing
applications to AWS.
- And lastly, an IDC study shows

how participants capture
value of VMware Cloud on AWS

by establishing VMware based
hybrid cloud environments
that delivers cost
and staff efficiencies

in addition to benefits
such as enhanced agility

and performance and
improved business results

compared with their previous
on-premises environment.

Further, they benefit from the
ease of application migration

compared with using another
native public cloud solutions.
VMware Cloud on AWS outshines on-premises
with 50% lower cost,
95% less downtime,
and 361% ROI.
- And that covers all of our main updates.

Let's move on to the
next segment of the show
where we'll bring in our first guest.
(playful music)
So, I know all of you watching this
are probably thinking
there's one big update,

one elephant in the room
that we have not covered yet.
And you're right.
This update is, of course,
that VMware is now a part of Broadcom.
So, in light of this acquisition,

we wanted to bring in a very
special guest from Broadcom.

Senior Director of Product
Management, Matt Dryer.
Hi, Matt.
Welcome to the show.
How's it going?
- Hi, guys.
Thank you so much for having me today.
- So, Matt, to kick things off,

you have a lot of
experience with VMC on AWS,
you've been here for a little while.

Can you tell us a little
bit about the history

and your view of the partnership
between VMware and AWS?
- You bet.

Yeah, it's been a part
of VMware Cloud on AWS
since the very beginning.
Narayan and I and a team of scrappy folks
put this thing together
seven years ago
and started growing it ever since.

And I think that's, you
know, in my honed view,

our partnership has really
never been stronger.
You know, we have really gone through

all kinds of expansion and
adjustments to the service,

you know, adding to the
fleet, adding to regions,
adding all kinds of awesome capabilities.

And I think that we are
on a very good trajectory
and I think, you know,

again, the partnership has
never looked as stronger
as healthy as it is right now.
- Awesome.

And so, given the recent
acquisition by Broadcom,
how will this, if at all,
impact the VMware Cloud on AWS offering?
- Good question.
Broadcom and acquiring VMware
has had a couple of really big
and, kind of, interesting goals
in terms of simplifying.

You know, VMware at the
time of acquisition,
like we're about 25 years old, right?
And along the way, sort of, amassed,
you know, all kinds of great technology
and a bit of technical debt, right?
And so, I think with Broadcom,
you know, being our new parent company,
there is this really strong pressure
to start simplifying.
And so, simplifying, I think,
it really does have a lots of very direct

and very, you know, rational
customer benefits, right?

Instead of having to,
you know, all through,

you know, hundreds or
thousands or tens of thousands
of different product offerings,
it's now very simple, right?
There are a couple of very large,
very nicely entitled bundles
that our customers can pick from.
And I think that
this is just gonna make everything
much simpler to understand,
much easier to transact.
And at the end of the day,
it gets much simpler
and much better for our customers.
It's no more of this like,

you know, putting together
this crazy puzzle.

It's, you know, what level
of software capabilities
do you need?
Is it VCF or vSphere Foundation,
you know, to run your environment.
And from there, you just go.
And so, I think that, you know,

we are going to continue
aligning these capabilities
between on-prem and VMware Cloud on AWS.

In fact, we're already
very, very close, right?
With VMware Cloud on AWS advanced,

you know, the software
entitlement in that bundle
is almost identical

to the software
entitlement to VCF on-prem.
And so, this whole thing becomes simpler.
It becomes, you know, just as powerful
as it has always been.

But it, I think, really
just has a lot of niceties
at the end of the day.
- Thanks, Matt.
I just wanna know,
how do you see

AWS and VMware partnership
evolving under the new structure?

- I think it's, you
know, full speed ahead.

I think that we have, you
know, re-ignited the roadmap

and have really started doing
much more cross training
between the field teams, the partner teams
and everything else.

If you just check the
recent set of blog releases
that we've done,
you can see everybody's running faster.
And so, I think that,

you know, personally, it's
been very reinvigorating,
you know, getting back to this pace.
And I think that,

you know, customers
are gonna see this too.

We're going to see, you
know, more instance types,
more features,
and lots of exciting stuff coming up.
- Fantastic.
Today, a lot of customers

are looking to optimize
their costs on infrastructure
so that they use the new found budget
on bringing innovation to the market.
So, from an economic point of view,
can you talk about how VMC on AWS
is compared to on-premises infrastructure
or other native cloud options?
- Absolutely.
So, we get this question all the time.
Like, why should I bother going to cloud?

And so, we've been doing
lots of economic studies,
internally with our customers
and also with third parties
to validate that,

you know, running workload
in VMware Cloud on AWS
is actually much less expensive
than running it on-prem.
In our most recent study,

and again, you can go
check the blog on this,
you know, we worked with IDC
to validate

that customers can actually
achieve a 53% savings
over running workloads on-prem.

This isn't just, you know,
VMware by Broadcom saying this,
this is actually third party validated.

And our customers have been
seeing this for a long time,
right?

Getting out of the data
center operations business
and really focusing your efforts

on delivering higher value
application services,
it's just sort of a no brainer.
And after you've run the models
and start seeing this in practice,
it becomes very, very evident

over a term of a year
or a couple of years.

Or frankly, even after you
get that migration done
over the course of a weekend.
- Cool, thank you.
So, Matt, at the start of this episode,

we went through a series of
new features and releases.

And so, with everything
that's been going on recently
around the product,
what are you most excited about?
- I'm super excited about M7i.
So, we've been launching new instances
throughout the course of the service.

You know, we started off
with the I3 instance type.
Then we brought on I3en, the I4i,
and now, most recently, M7i.
The thing that I love about M7i is,
it goes back and addresses a price point
that was, you know,

causing us a little bit
of problems actually.
So, our smaller customers

that just wanted to
bring a few workloads in,
maybe it's a small migration,

small data center that
we're trying to get rid of,
you know, some of the big iron is
just frankly not a perfect fit for that.
And so, with M7i
and disaggregated storage,

we've got a whole new set
of architectural tools
for customers to work with
to sort of right size that migration

and put the right workload
in the right spot.
And so, you're gonna see more of this.

You're gonna see, you
know, more instance types,
more flexibility and the sizes
and the types of SDDCs that you deploy,

and ultimately really
try to optimize that cost

and make sure that you're
squeezing every penny
out of your infrastructure purchases.
- You have been an awesome guest, Matt.
Thanks for joining us.
To close things out,

do you have any parting
thoughts, comments, or plugs?
- I'm just so happy to be on this journey.
And I think we all really are.
I mean, the world of technology
and the world of cloud
moves so very, very quickly.
And I think that we really are solving
some critical customer pain points here,
and I think we're gonna continue to do so
for many years to come.
So, thank you everybody
for being on this journey with us,
and I look forward to many more years
of providing the service.
Thank you.
- Amazing.
Thanks for joining us.
- Thanks, Matt.
(playful music)

- Our next topic is VMware
Cloud Disaster Recovery.
And joining us today on the show
is Greg Vinton,

who's a Specialist
Solution Architect at AWS.
Greg, welcome to the show.

We'd love to hear more about
VMware Cloud Disaster Recovery.
- Hi, Senay. Hi, Dries.
Thank you for having me on the show.
Appreciate the time

and I'm sure you're having
a great show already.

I'm here to talk about VMware
Cloud Disaster Recovery.

I wanna take you through
two main topics today.
The first, I'll give you a short overview
of what VMware Cloud Disaster Recovery is.
And then, I'd love to take you

through some of the
updates that have come out.
We've actually had a huge drop of updates
in this latest release.

So, what is VMware
Cloud Disaster Recovery?

It is an on-demand disaster
recovery as a service.
So, it's a SaaS based service
for customers to protect their workloads.
Now, on the slide that you'll see
on the screen in front of you now,
I'll just take you through that quickly.
So, on the very left hand side,
you can see there is what we refer to as
a production site
or a protected site.
Now, that protected site

can sit in both your
on-premise data center,
VMware Cloud on AWS
or some of the other hyperscalers.
The only thing that needs to be deployed
into your protected site
is what we call the DRaaS Connector,
and that's a really lightweight appliance.
Now, in the middle there,
you can see the cloud-based services.
There's really two components to that.
You have the SaaS Orchestrator.

That's essentially your
front end or your GUI

where you manage both
your protection plans
and your disaster recovery plans.

And then we have the
Scale-out File System.

This is where we protect
the workloads into,
and that is based on storage
that is very durable
and hosted across AWS regions.
Now, up until that point,
that is really all you need
and all you pay for for VCDR.
Now, during a disaster or during testing,

that's when you're gonna
need a recovery site.
So, the recovery site,
you have two flavors.
We have what we call pilot light.
Now, with a pilot light recovery site,
that is up and running all the time,

ready to take on testing or
disaster recovery workloads.

So, the recovery time
objective can be quite low.
Now, for customers that perhaps don't need

a very, very low recovery
time objective or RTO,

they can have no pilot
lights site sitting there.
So, what that means is

during testing when you
actually have a DR event,
that's when you deploy your recovery site.

And that recovery site will
always sit in VMware Cloud
on AWS.

Now, so with VCDR, it
is an on-demand service.

So, you're only gonna
pay for infrastructure
when you need to use it.
It's very easy to use.

So, it's very easy to set
up your protection groups,

and it's very easy to set up
your disaster recovery plans

as well as testing those
recovery plans as well.

And then finally, because
it's on demand as a service,

it means it can be very
commercially viable

for customers that are looking
for a disaster recovery plan
and solution

without having to pay for
in expensive infrastructure
that's sitting there all of the time.
Now, as I mentioned,
there was another part
that I wanted to take you through as well.
We've had a huge number of updates,

actually 14 updates in the
latest release of VCDR.

And I'll take you through a
number of those updates now.
You'll see in the list there

that we've got some updates
highlighted in green.

I'll go through those in
a little bit more detail,
but we'll cover all the updates today.
So, the first one's a big one.

It's the 15 minute RPO has
gone general availability.
So, for customers

that are looking for a lower
recovery point objective,
they can now get that down to 15 minutes.
Prior to this update,
this was sitting at a 30 minute RPO.
Now, for customers that need to go
lower than that 15 minute RPO,

we have other options
within the AWS services

as well as some of our
VMware solutions as well
can provide that lower RPO.
The next update

is the support for VMware
cloud on AWS compute gateways
on the recovery SDDC.
So, what that means for customers is
they can recover workloads
into their software-defined data center,
which is sitting in VMware Cloud on AWS.

They can recover their
production workloads
sitting on a specific compute gateway.
They can also recover,
say, ransomware infected workloads

into the same software
defined data center,

but on to a completely
separate compute gateway.

This means that I can have
these infected workloads

that I'm looking at to
recover from and fix
without having them in the same network
as production workloads.

The next update is support
for the VMware Transit Connect
on the VMware Cloud on AWS protected site.
So, this means my protected sites
can now sit on the same networks
as my other AWS services
or VMware Cloud on AWS environments.

I can also recover from
ransomware cleanse workloads
to the recovery SDDC.
What this means for customers

is they can now have more
VMware restore options

to make sure that they
can clean their workloads.
This gives you more fine tuned models

to be able to recover from
those ransomware infections
or malware infections as well,
which really means

that you're gonna increase
your cyber resiliency

through the runbooks that
you can set up within VCDR.
We also have updated the quiescing
for high frequency snapshots.

Now, this is really
important for customers
that have workloads such as databases
where they need consistency
in those snapshots.
So, with this,

it means that you can
have a consistent based
copy of your database,
so in recovering that,

it is gonna be consistent
with your requirements.

And the way this works with
your high frequency snapshots
is it pauses the running state of the VM
while it's taking that snapshot,
which causes that consistency.
The next update is the automatic install
of Linux security sensor

when using the ransomware
recovery workflow.

We've also increased the
usability enhancements
for guest file recovery.
So, not many people know

that you can also use
VCDR to recover files.

So, you can recover individual
files using VCDR as well.
And so, there's been some enhancements
in the usability for that.
We've also increased,
or enabled I should say,

to be able to pause the failback
before the VM shuts down,

so you can now have
that in your DR runbook.

We've also added into the
DR runbook failback retry.
Now, what that means is

that if you have a process
that fails during your testing
or during your disaster recovery,
rather than failing the whole DR,

it's actually gonna go back
and try and retry that step
in your DR plan.

So, a really good
example for this might be
that one particular application or VM
needs to wait for another virtual machine
to be up and running
before it can continue on.

Now, if that process was to
fail the first time around,

that would end the whole
disaster recovery plan
and you need to fix that.
With this update,

it'll essentially retry
that step a couple of times,
and if that can continue going,

that disaster recovery plan
can continue going on as well.
The next update
is the ability to detach your SDDC
without deleting it.
So, prior to this update,
when you detached your recovery SDDC
from your VCDR solution,
it would essentially delete that SDDC.
So, this means for customers
they no longer have to spend time
setting up that recovery SDDC.
We've also increased

the maximum number of
concurrent protection groups
from five to 10,

which means you can essentially
protect more workloads
at the same time,
which is a really good update.
The next update

is around the Carbon
Black portal integration.

Now, we've changed the location
of that from within VCDR.
Essentially, it makes it more usable,
user friendly I should say,
for customers
that are using Carbon Black

to be able to recover from
ransomware infections.

We've also updated the number
of countries and regions

that ransomware recovery data
processing has been added to.
And then finally,

we've enabled the ability
to switch protection groups
from high frequency snapshots
to standard frequency snapshots.
So, what this means for customers is
they can change the type of snapshotting

without needing to recreate
their protection groups.
So, it makes a lot easier for customers
to change those types of snapshots
when they need
without adding on additional work.
So, that's it for the updates.

As you can see, there's
a huge number of updates
that have come out this month.
And you'll see this consistently
with both VCDR
as well as VMware Cloud on AWS.

This continually adding on
new features, new services
that customers can consume.

So, that's what I wanted to
take you and the team through
and our customers through today.
So, back to you both in the studio.
- Thanks, Greg,
for all the updates
and your time.

It's been great pleasure
having you on the show.
- Thanks so much for joining us, Greg.
(playful music)

- And that wraps up another
episode of the Update Show.
It's been super fun

to talk about the latest
and greatest updates
in the world of VMware and AWS.
Thank you so much for joining us.
To get more information,
Dries, where should our viewers go?

- You can find more
information on the AWS website.
Just search for VMware.
And we'll have an information

on all of the updates
covered in this month's show
in the description below,
as well as how to get in touch
with a representative from AWS.

With that, thank you to all
of you who tuned in today.
- Thank you,
and goodbye.
